Reviews.Title: Unbelievable picture!  Does require some tweaking.
Reviews.Author: D. Matheny
Reviews.Content: I have to admit that I've been completely blown away by how fast flat screen technology has evolved in the last few years.Just 5 years ago, the smallest bezel TV I could find was a 52" Mitsubishi LCD; and, now I was able to purchase this 55" Samsung LED that looks small when hanging in the same cabinet - even with the 3" larger screen!When I first set this TV up, I was initially impressed with the bright colors; but, there were 3 obvious problems:- There was an almost unnoticeable 'glitch' that would occur fairly frequently.  I tried to tell myself I was just being picky; but, it happened often enough to be irritating.- The picture was absolutely crystal clear (like looking out a window) - but the colors made everything look like a soap opera.  (At least, that's what I thought of.)- The picture looked great when the room was bright; but, it got a hazy/grey look when the room was dark.I started playing with the settings and lucked into a fix for the glitch pretty quickly.  There's a setting called 'Auto Motion Plus' under 'Picture Options'.  I played around with it for a bit and realized the glitch completely disappeared when this is set to 'Off'.The problem with the 'soap opera' look was resolved by messing with the color settings; and, the most important change ended up being to reduce the brightness & LED backlight settings.The haziness took a few days - and I almost reached a point where I was going to return the TV.  Fortunately, that was also resolved by turning off the 'Eco Sensor'.  The reason it took longer to find is because it isn't located under picture settings - instead, it's hidden in the 'System/Eco Solution' menu...Anyway, I have to say that I'm 100% satisfied now - and absolutely blown away by the amazing picture quality!  I was tempted to reduce this to a 4 star review because I think the settings I mentioned should probably be defaults for most people; but, I'm sure Samsung has their own reasons.Overall, I would highly recommend this TV if you're looking for a great LED TV![*** UPDATE 8/10/2013 ***]I've continued messing with the settings on this TV and have found that the Eco-Sensor actually can be a nice feature.  Instead of turning it off, I started using the 'Minimum Brightness' sub-setting that forces the TV to stay above a specific brightness level.When the room was at it's darkest level (which is how it normally is when watching movies), I set the minimum brightness level on the Eco-Sensor so it looks good.  The great thing about that is the picture is now bright enough during the day and doesn't get the 'hazy' look at night.Anyway, I figured I would throw that one additional tip in here from my experimentation.

Reviews.Title: Three TVs enter. One TV leaves.
Reviews.Author: Chris G
Reviews.Content: (Note: to skip my long-winded story and read only about the FH6030, go to "TV #3" below)***Background: I had a 42" Panasonic PX600u plasma for seven years and loved it. But the set started to lose its luster, and I was tired of lowering the blinds during the day to watch TV. Most plasmas sold seven years ago did not have the best anti-glare coatings. So, I decided to go with an LED, knowing I would have to make some sacrifices in picture quality, but would in turn gain a set that was much brighter and performed significantly better in daylight.***The Goal: 50-55" with a great picture for around $1000. I didn't care about 3D or Smart features. I have an AppleTV and PlayStation that handle the Smart features. Unless your TV will be mounted somewhere that can't accommodate any additional devices, there's no need to ever use a TV's built in Netflix, Hulu, etc. They are horrible at it compared to AppleTV, Roku, Xbox/PS3, etc.I did not want to have to go through three TVs  to get one I liked. But if I was spending $1000 for something I would hope to have for ten years, I was going to be picky.***TV #1: What sucks about buying a TV is that you can't judge the picture in stores because the settings are all jacked up and you're viewing under florescent lighting. Your best bet is to do a ton of research online. But what I discovered is that many TV manufacturers have different panel makers for the same model, and those panels can perform very differently. CNET may rave about one model, and you can get the same model with a different panel and have poor result. With that said, I found a great deal for a 50" 2012 Samsung ES6500. Reviews online were mixed, ranging from stellar (Consumer Reports) to just OK (PC Mag). Given Amazon's fantastic return policy, I ordered it. The picture wasn't bad. However, the details in dark scenes were horrible. In addition, this TV just wasn't that bright -- the main reason I switched from plasma to LED. The TV also exhibited some pretty bad "clouding" and "flashlighting" (terms I learned on AVS Forum when I found a thread full of people who hate this TV). Apparently, this is common for many edge-lit LEDs, but this model is much worse than most. I gave it about a week and returned the set.***TV #2: Even though it had no reviews, everyone loves Sony. I took a risk on a 50" 2013 Sony R550a. The problems I had with this Sony made me miss the previous Samsung:- It was even dimmer than the Samsung (and I had the Eco settings off)- No matter what I did, I couldn't get the picture to "pop" and give me any sort of wow factor- Not as important, but the Sony was pretty ugly in person and the chrome stand and bottom bezel created annoying reflections- It did not handle fast motion in a hockey game well- It's a semi-matte screen, but still not very good in a bright room- And most of all, when the camera panned during hockey, soccer or golf, it had this annoying cloudy effect. After doing some research, I found out this is called a dirty scree effect (DSE).I gave the Sony more than a week, but just couldn't get past the picture issues so I returned it. Also, I don't know if this means anything, but apparently the new Sony models are made with LG Panels.***TV #3: I read great early reviews on Samsung's 2013 TVs, so I took another risk and ordered the 55" FH6030. I've had it now for five days and LOVE it. Here is how it compares to the previous two TVs:- Very mild dirty screen effect. I have to look for it to see it. With the Sony R550a, I could not escape it. I don't recall if the ES6500 had DSE as I didn't even know what it was then, and it didn't stand out like the Sony- Much more uniform and has less flash-lighting and clouding compared to the ES6500. It's also better than the R550a in this department, but the Sony wasn't that bad to begin with. It's important to note that the FH6030 is direct-lit unlike the previous two TVs that were edge-lit. This makes the cabinet slightly thicker, but typically allows for a more uniform picture.- Much better shadow detail and performance in dark scenes than the ES6500, but not quite as good as the Sony R550a- Much brighter than both the ES6500 and R550a- Handles glare much better than the R550a and slightly better than the ES6500- The picture "pops" far more than the R550a- Off-angle viewing is not the greatest and worse than both the R550a and ES6500- No issues in handling fast motion. It's better than the R550a and pretty much the same as the ES6500I'm giving it five stars because I'm factoring price in. But if I'm rating the TV without factoring in cost, then the poor off-angle viewing and less than impressive detail in very dark scenes would make me drop it to four.Still, I'm happy enough with this TV to write my first Amazon review. After being very frustrated from having to return two prior TVs, I feel somewhat victorious for finally landing a set I love.

Reviews.Title: Great 3D TV
Reviews.Author: Frankl8593
Reviews.Content: Just picked this up a few days ago. Since this is a new 2013 model, there is conflicting information on websites as to whether this tv supports 3D or not.  It does.  Visit Samsung's website for full details.  This FH6030 is pretty much the same as last years EH6030, but does not have the 3D glasses included and is at a lower retail price.Wanted a 3D TV but had no use for Smart features (streaming Netflix, Amazon, etc) as my TV is hooked up to my HTPC. This is one of the very few TV's with 3D and no Smart features. And it's priced accordingly. Easy to set up and fairly light if you are doing a wall mounting. Picture is good as expected with any Samsung product and has multiple setup options. Connects to the internet but the connection is used only for software updates.  Like so many others, I really don't care for the Auto Motion or LED Motion Plus features that smooth the picture.  Others call this the "Soap Opera" effect, but what it really does, to my eyes, is reduce sharpness and blur out/soften/dim the picture.  I just turn them off.No 3D glasses are included, but they are less than 20 dollars a pair. The correct glasses to get are the Samsung SSG-5100GB 3D Active Glasses. Pair them with the set (they are bluetooth) and you're good to go. The 2D to 3D conversion is surprisingly good. The 3D is outstanding.If you want a nice 55 inch TV with 3D and don't need to stream from the TV, this is the one to get.http://www.amazon.com/Samsung-SSG-5100GB-3D-Active-Glasses/dp/B00BIP816Q/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid;=1370206449&sr;=8-3&keywords;=3d+glasses+for+Samsung

Reviews.Title: Factory settings look terrible.  Looks good after custom adjustment.
Reviews.Author: M. J. Bernadett
Reviews.Content: We use this TV for 3 different content sources:1.  SD A/V from a Comcast cable box.2.  HD QAM-in-the-clear for local channels.  Update 9/20/13 NOT CURRENTLY RECEIVING THESE!3.  PS3 via HDMI for games, Netflix, DVD and Blu RayI was really worried when we first fired this set up.  The SD A/V looked terrible, and the HD local channels didn't look a whole lot better.  People's faces were washed out, flat and blurry.I discovered I need to TURN OFF DYNAMIC CONTRAST, and crank the contrast DOWN.  In general, turn OFF all the settings that pretend to be smart in how they trade off one thing for another.  Things with 'Filtering', 'Auto', or 'Reduction' in the name are all enabled from the factory, but you probably don't need all of them, or you may be able to adjust most of them to a lower level.With Dynamic Contrast off, an adjustment procedure that worked well for us:1. Do this in the evening or in a dimly lit room.2. Set backlight to a mid to low value like 9.3. Set contrast to 50.4. Set sharpness to a low value like 40.5. Adjust brightness so that absolute black in the picture is really black, with no hint of gray.  You may need to switch channels to find a movie with dark scenes, or put up a news channel that has black in the crawl, like Bloomberg.  You can switch the picture size to bring up black bars to compare with.  Set it just to the point where the hint of gray is gone.6. Now adjust the backlight to get the picture brightness right for your lighting conditions.  From here on, leave 'brightness' alone, and use backlight to adjust for different room lighting.I believe 50 is 'unity' for contrast, i.e. a transfer function slope of 1.  Adjust according to your tastes, but be aware that 100 is the extreme high setting, not 'normal' or unity.  Don't expect 'sharpness' to do much, unless you're watching 20th century soap operas or an old episode of 'fawlty towers'.  Also, the MPEG filtering looks better on 'low' for us.For the A/V input, you may find that 'game mode' gives you a better picture, simply because it bypasses some of the 'smart' processing that doesn't work so well for SD (480i).  Game mode is selected elsewhere in the menus, under System Settings.Fortunately there is a separate memory store of all these settings for each input.My recommendation is to go through all the inputs you'll be using, start with all the extra features turned off, then add in just enough of the feature that's most important to you and go from there.Most people don't like the 'Soap Opera Effect' that Auto Motion Plus gives you on fictional content like movies and dramas.  Since it removes the 'judder' and 'motion blur' that you ordinarily get with 24fps material, it tends to make the content look less like a movie and more like a soap opera shot at 29.97fps (59.94i).  In HD it actually makes things look more real, so it makes a movie look like a bunch of people walking around a movie set.  It takes away quite a bit of the drama or fiction 'feel' of the 24fps we're used to, and reveals details that the director didn't necessarily intend.No problems with 3D from the PS3.  Clear, accurate and lifelike.  Two thumbs up on that.Bought mine on sale at Best Buy for the same price I see here.

Reviews.Title: Excellent value on a top-tier brand TV.
Reviews.Author: Kenneth B. Kaczor
Reviews.Content: At the $700 sale price tag, it was probably the best value for a 3D LCD TV at the time, with a fantastic picture sitting at front center although lackluster off-viewing angles.The 3D is very good.  Many people bash 3D and call it a gimmick--which it often is--but done right it really adds to the experience.There are no Smart features on this TV, and it is not wifi-capable.  HOWEVER, you CAN connect it via ethernet to update it if one ever becomes available (I doubt it--this seems more like a yearly value model) and--this surprised me--you CAN stream content over your network, and it apparently even can see my plex server without any special configuration (!).  And as another reviewer helpfully pointed out, it does play MKVs. NOTE, if you are using this to connect to a PC, I could not force a 120hz input.  It is no replacement for a 120hz monitor as most TVs, like this one, cannot accept a 120hz signal.  It is also VERY important that you tell the TV that this is a PC by pressing SOURCE on the remote, selecting the input, then pressings TOOLS and naming it as "PC." This does more than just name your input--it is actually a specific PC mode that disables all the unnecessary crap and displays a proper image to the PC.  You will also need to change your picture size by pressing "P. Size" on your remote and selecting "screen fit."  Your image will likely appear either too large for the screen or not take up the entire TV screen, in which case you actually have to go to your video card's settings and changing the overscan/underscan until it is just right.It should also be mentioned that the input delay is a bit noticeable even after game mode and PC mode are selected, when compared to monitors.  This should have the greatest effect on online twitch-shooter games.  It will likely not be a factor in most games.

Reviews.Title: 5 for the video, 3 for the audio
Reviews.Author: whwh
Reviews.Content: I have the 55" version of this 3DTV. Video is wonderful. It's like looking through glass. But the video is not quite so good out of the box. So I would suggest tinkering with all settings. - There is the Picture category of options, but then there are other video-related options in the System category of options.It seems like the key things to adjust is to turn Eco-Mode off and never turn on the Motion Lighting.And there are 4 settings, Dynamic, Standard, Natural, and Movie. These differ in how they are preset but they also differ slightly in image and light focus or in how the light diffuses over objects in a scene. Everything else being equal, color settings, warm or cold, brightness settings, etc, going from one setting to the other will seem as different as changing light sources from a campfire or a incandescent light bulb to a flourescent light bulb or LED.For my viewing, the best starting point is "Movie" and modifying from there. Movie is the most natural for both the colors and the light focus, and for all of its Pros has the most minimal Cons. Dynamic, OTOH, is a sharp and vivid when modified properly but ultimately suffers too much from "black crush" where darks and shadows tend to look indistinguishable from each other. "Natural" is pre-set pretty good but is horrible in the way that it handles scene changes (brightness levels change a split second before the scene does). Also, in Natural and Dynamic, you cannot change Advance Options.Here's an example qualia I get from this TV in Movie: Looking at wooden floors in videos is like looking at wooden floors in real life. The same goes for hair- you can see each strand. You'll see every damp crack in concrete sidewalks or flooring. You'll even see water stains on windows. It's like looking through glass, great details, great balance between light and dark.My settings in Movie:Backlight 19Contrast 100Brightness 55Sharpness 55Color 69Tint  45Dynamic Contrast OffBlack Tone OffFlesh Tone 0Color Space NativeWhite Balance R-Offset 10 G-Offset 10 B-Offset 10- The rest at default 25Gamma -2.Picture Options: Color Tone Standard, Auto Motion Plus - Custom (4 for Blur Reduction 5 Judder)When used as a PC monitor make sure you calibrate using the "calibrate display" program native to Windows. It's usually located at C:\Windows\System32\dccw.exe. I use the above settings and then calibrate. Also make sure to change desktop icon fonts and web browser fonts, as the font will be too thin to see comfortably with sharpness turned up.(Important edit: Whenever you change resolution on your computer, the Samsung TV automatically switches to PC mode; you lose about half of the options avaiable, and the picture looks awful. Go to source and then tools and then change the source to Game; this way you get back a fuller picture. If the PC screen doesn't line up with the TV screen, select "Screen Fit" option in the Screen Adjustment category. In PC mode, the Samsung TV is too dark, or way too bright, with no viewing middle ground, and with a lot of grey in between.)The "Soap Opera" effect? I kind of like it, although a better term for it would be the "Green Screen effect" - since when you watch it always seems as though actors are in front of a green screen with a digital environment added after the fact, which is often the reality anyway. Almost reminds me of the cut-scenes used in older SCiFi video games featuring live action and live actors within fake, CG, environments. This effect can be turned off so it's no big deal, like it or not. You can also vary its intensity.(Postedit 2: I am in love with the above feature. Take full advantage of the Soap Opera effect, by choosing custom. The reward is a life-like viewing experience. The active variable behind the SO Effect is Judder Reduction, and what it does is move the background with the foreground  in the vertical direction wherever it sees fit (kind of like the way Youtube videos have a post-processing option to remove all shaking in a video, but much better and much subtler). Too little JR and you get a lot of tiny movement, and too much judder reduction, and you get a lot of wide, sweeping, overall motion with not a lot of stability. The idea is to get it at just the right intensity where the viewing correction closely emulates that of looking at things in real life, with the eyeballs moving, with the head moving. I have the Blur Reduction set to 4 and the Judder Reduction set to 5. This seems to be the best combination.)What I don't like about the TV is the audio. I have a soundbar so that takes care of that. But the Samsung speakers really do leave a lot to be desired when compared to the speakers on other TVs. There's also a considerable lag I notice in the audio when I hook the TV up to my computer. The lag goes away when I have use my soundbar, but buyers would do well to consider this.The form factor isn't the best. You want the best? Spend 500-1000 more and buy the TVs with glass bezels, chrome pod stands, and that are  2inches deep. This TV isn't quite as sexy, although the bezel is thin.Finally, I have tried out the 3D. It's a good feature and adds depth to 2D. However, I'm not crazy about it.Overall, this TV is awesome for the price. A 3D, LED backlit TV with none of the expensive (and useless) SmartTV excesses - I say useless because I have my PC hooked up to the TV  anyway, which would make it an EinsteinTV. See what I did there?

Reviews.Title: SHOULD BE FLYING OFF THE SHELVES
Reviews.Author: Chris Kennison
Reviews.Content: I've spent a few weeks now with the Samsung 40" 3D tv and I have never been more satisfied with a purchase in my life. I'm a movie nut job. I know, many people are, but you don't understand; I'm crazy nuts and ever since the 3D craze started, I've been giddy like a child that Hollywood was bringing it back and doing it well. For that same amount of time I've been salivating over 3D-tv's that I couldn't afford and it was leaving knots in my stomach. I was literally obsessed with owning a 3D tv. Financially, it wasn't an option and it made it almost impossible to bear. I'm a single father and caring for my son was taking all of my discretionary income.  That ended with the Samsung 40" 3D tv.Samsung is the #1 tv brand on the market for a reason; or at least one of the tops. They are smart enough to realize that people aren't buying 3D tvs because their too pricey. Right after the market told everybody to buy HD-tv's, and people did, they said, "Now buy 3D tvs".  Well.... we just bought HD-TV's.... now we have to buy something else in order to get 3D!?  People wanted 3D-tv's but the government was busy destroying the economy and giving tax dollars to terrorist countries to fund Al-queda and Bin Laden. I'm rambling, but this is all relevant.  Bottom line... HERE IT IS.  Finally, Samsung has delivered a remarkable 3D-tv with a jaw-dropping price.You may think, "it must suck."  You'd be wrong. The trick is that it isn't a 'smart-tv'. Well, in this day and age of PS3, PS4 and Xbox, you don't have to have a 'smart' tv to have a smart-tv. Playstation and Xbox do all that, so buying a 3D-tv with smart capability and owning a PS or Xbox is an oxymoron and a waste of money. This TV has a brilliant picture and a brilliant 3D that after watching for weeks now, I believe is even better than what you would experience at the movie theater and I've had 4 other people say the same thing to me.Samsung has made a brilliant move here. In a world of hundreds of millions of people who already have smart capability with gaming systems, they delivered a brilliant 3D-tv at a jaw-dropping low price. This is it. Grab it. I assure you. It is well worth it. Be smart. Just because your hair-dresser is cheap doesn't mean she's bad. Just because your neighbor kid wants $30 to shovel your driveway, doesn't mean he's gonna do a $30 job.  The Samsung 40" 3D is a steal. No, the glasses don't come with it, but LOOK AT THAT PRICE... you can buy Samsung SSG-5100GB 3D active glasses for $15 each. It does have a little bit of a glare in sunny room and it does take some tweaking to suit your liking, but that is nothing compared to the benefits. Most notably, it took me a while to find a setting called L/R image & R/L image. The 3D didn't look good; like the background was more prominent, but when I switched this to R/L.... all look like it was supposed to and the party began.Have fun!!  And make sure you tell all your jealous friends when they watch it for a bit that you paid a little more than $400 for it. Then take pictures of their jaws dropping.

Reviews.Title: Samsung UN55FH6030
Reviews.Author: Sabrewings
Reviews.Content: I'll keep this one short and sweet.  This is an excellent TV.  I've had it just a few months, but its clarity has already impressed me.  I have it wall mounted which was pretty easy.  Follow other reviewers on settings and you'll have a great looking TV.  I use it as a monitor for my home theater/ gaming machine, as well as for my 360, Roku, and Blu-Ray.  All of it looks beautiful.I did get the extended warranty plan just for piece of mind, knowing a few people who have had to use them.  So far I've found one stuck pixel, but it doesn't bother me.  I only notice it while internet browsing, and I understand that it is something that happens with most panels and a 100% stuck pixel free panel is rare.

Reviews.Title: Great TV!!
Reviews.Author: Paul Juliano
Reviews.Content: If you've got a receiver, this is the TV for you. It doesn't have a lot of HDMI inputs (Who cares? you've got a receiver for that!), the speakers suck (So don't all TV speakers!), there are no smart apps (My PS3's got plenty...)It DOES have an amazing picture and a great price. You can't beat this screen at this price.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful Picture, Full Sound.
Reviews.Author: Alexander Lewis Schaeffer
Reviews.Content: Beautiful picture even while hooked up to my computer and watching Netflix. The sound is amazing for the fact that it's from the Television speakers, easily fills the room and is very full. Perfect size for average or small living room and bedrooms. If you don't care about the smart TV aspect of the 40 inch Samsung, it's worth saving the the money and buying this one.Highly recommend this for someone who is searching for the best 39-42 in LED HDTV.

Reviews.Title: Don't let the lack of ports stop you
Reviews.Author: Brickhaus
Reviews.Content: Great picture. No complains after a few months of use. Can play .mkv files from the USB port. This TV is only cheap because of the lack of HDMI (2) and USB (1) ports. Otherwise you are getting a solid Samsung product with a great picture.

Reviews.Title: Best 3D for the price, no frills.  All the Smart TV stuff that other TVs have not needed.
Reviews.Author: Tooth
Reviews.Content: Just got the TV delivered this morning!For comparison purposes...I already have a 58" Panasonic Plasma V10 (few years old for $2500) which is a very highly rated TV.  Purchased a 60" Samsung UN60F6300 Smart TV (4 months ago ($1100) for the office.  The Panasonic has excellent picture quality.  The Samsung has good picture quality, the Smart TV features I don't even use.  Wifi and LAN connection on it don't work well.  Didn't want to return the TV due to the network issue, it was HARD to hang it high up on the wall.The UN55FH6030 has better picture quality than BOTH of the other TVs and for only $699.  Played a BluRay and the picture quality looks real.I tried the 3D with the 5100 Active glasses.  The main object looks 1080P, but the background is blurry and the lighting is bright in some areas.  Since we watch mostly 2D, I'm happy with the picture quality.  UPDATE: I fixed the background issue.  In 3D menu, some movies or games need to be L->R, while others R->L picture.Another reviewer mentioned the stand.  The TV does wobble even with the stand installed, maybe because it is held in by 8 small screws.  That's the only negative about this TV, if it had a stronger stand would be nice.  If you're wall mounting, not an issue.

Reviews.Title: great T.V
Reviews.Author: pinskyj
Reviews.Content: This samsung TV is great. The graphics and great, and I like how the brightness of the screen adjusts to degree of light which the room has. 3D on it is better then I have had anticipated. I am very happy with this purchase.  Best  LED TV out there in my opinion!

Reviews.Title: Christmas Present
Reviews.Author: sksgrlvol
Reviews.Content: Love this TV!!!! Played and played with setting. I have the sensors and auto motion turned off. I set my TV on the dynamic mode and finally have the colors where I want them.Backlight 9Contrast 100Brightness 25Sharpness 100Color 40Tint G71-R29Very very pleased with my picture now and movies look great, glad this was included with HDMI cords. Needed!!! Another suggestion buy a sound bar for surround sound. This is our first flat screen. We still had an old tube tv.

Reviews.Title: Significant ghosting and judder
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: I realize the overwhelmingly positive reviews for this TV so maybe I got a defective one. I first tested Pirates of the Carribean on Blu Ray to gauge the picture quality. While it was overall very nice, there was significant "judder," (i.e., jagged motion) that happened randomly, especially during fast-moving scenes. Then, I put in my Perks of Being a Wallflower Blu Ray. The "ghosting" (i.e., smeared motion) was constant, at least once every minute or so. I couldn't watch it.I was willing to forgive this TV having only two HDMI ports (seriously, my four-year-old 60hz TV had FOUR HDMI ports), but the motion picture quality made this unworthy of a good review. I will be returning this.

Reviews.Title: Da Vinci Perspective refined
Reviews.Author: Amazon Shopper
Reviews.Content: I love it. After being really disappointed for the first 24 hours. The state of the art has come a long way in HDTV offerings. A market sector we have all generously provided with R&D; funds as the technology has emerged. Why Do I Love it? The picture quality is comparable to my high quality Computer Graphic Displays. This may seem like a strange comparison, however consider that even modest LED panels deliver pretty good to fabulous results when fed by GPU/CPU engines delivering entertainment in the form of Games and Motion Picture releases.The 3D Feature is there, like the sliding glass door that greets you're mug on occasion before it is opened. It converts your 2D into 3D, I think. The Gossamer thin chassis, like fine linen, is incredibly light. Initial setup is easy, however mine booted into the default "horrible picture quality mode"? i.e. the ambient light sensor determined I was not blind then proceeded to reduce picture quality sufficiently to cause blurred vision.Xbox Live - Yowza!, Netflix, Hulu Plus Amazon Prime? Yep, Glorious.What is not convenient - Game Mode, which is buried and hidden like an embarrassing rash, deep in the forgotten bowels of the menu system that otherwise does what menu systems do, without being too annoying. Literally the last menu option (under SYSTEM) in a row of options nowhere near the usual picture tweak options, leading to a submenu option as if to suggest --- Seriously? You're going to play a game? Yes....eventually...The Energy Star Option is there and upon first view is terrible, consistent with the industry practice of making consumers suffer to save some planet warming energy. It's a dumb practice that should change. Start with the ambient light sensor which has not worked in a meaningful manner across the last three premium brands I purchased. Yes it dims, often to the point of cataract inducing pointlessness. I discovered a trick after letting the appliance break-in for a week, setting it to standard picture mode, then optionally set to game mode, touching nothing else. I can enable Energy Star. I then drill the options below it and bumped one parameter by one point. Magically the picture reveals the glorious cinematic joy I had hoped for and now possess!Low power consumption, extraordinary picture quality, fantastic 60P frame rates for gaming...once you locate game mode. Yes- you will probably want to turn game mode of again for streaming of other entertainment-unless the game console provides the content. Maybe...For the price I am very happy...like really happy...totally happy...ecstatically rapturous.it only took 4 HDTV set replacements from different premium manufactures to finally get one that looks as good or better than my computer screens. Yah!Buy one...you deserve it.

Reviews.Title: Great TV, Great Value
Reviews.Author: Chris Rich
Reviews.Content: So, after many years, we finally upgraded from our old 29" tube Samsung TV to this model. Believe me, I never purchase anything without doing a lot of research, and I did as such. Lot's of research, about 3-4 weeks of it before I decided on this TV. I also looked at TVs at a couple of big box stores, and Samsung TVs looked better than other brands by a long shot.I didnt care about the 3D, this was just a bonus really. I didn't need any fancy bells & whistles, just a TV.I had it narrowed down to this model or the Samsung UN46EH5000. We went with this model for the higher refresh rate for just a little bit more money. Now there are some reviewers on here giving bad reviews for picture quality, saying the TV looks terrible. I am convinced these people just don't know how to set it up, or are not hooking the right cables into it. Yes, this TV needs to be calibrated when you set it up, the factory settings are not that good. It's not that hard to do, a little research, a little time & "wah la" this TV looks friggin" amazing. I love the fact this TV has so many different settings, which allows you to really dial it in. There is a great review in these reviews from a very knowledgeable reviewer, that tells you how to dial it in. I didn't go exactly with his settings, but it definatly was a good starting point.All in all, I am very pleased with this TV. The picture clarity is awesome, the colors rich and vivid, the controls allow you to dial in every aspect of the TV, & with the thin bevel design, the TV looks great too. Would recommend to anybody.

Reviews.Title: Great TV if you can catch it on sale
Reviews.Author: Brad the Tech Wizard
Reviews.Content: Where to begin? Well, I got this TV during the black Friday sale. Price was $699 and with my Prime Membership, shipping was fast and free. The TV weighs about 25 lbs so shipping, set up and moving have all been easy with this TV. Samsung really did a great job with this one in terms of weight vs picture quality. But let's get down to the good stuff.The picture quality is superb. It's like night and day over my aged LG LCD TV. To clarify, this Samsung is an LED HDTV which helps account for why it's so lightweight but has stunning images. 55 inches is more than enough for the average living room and this sits wonderfully in mine. I'm a heavy tech enthusiasts so I did my research before buying so let me tell you why I chose this one.120hz - This TV rocks 120hz which is what everyone should all want (at least 120hz) but don't automatically assume that means you are forced into the "soap opera" effect. That effect is handled by a different setting, in fact 2, called Judder Reduction and Blur Reduction/Removal. Both have custom sliders for you to set the effects to however strong or light you want which is a great design choice.  Personally, I like the "soap opera" effect because, to me, it makes the picture more life-like. And honestly, isn't that what everyone is going for in a TV? How beautiful and life like the images are? Well then crank Judder Reduction and Blur Removal up to 5 and try it out. It's a nice middle ground.Stunning display - This TV is beautiful to look at. Pacfic Rim, The Hobbit, Star Wars, How to Train Your Dragon, all looked dazzling on this TV. You will find tweaking the settings makes things look better, but I found that, right out of the box, this TV delivered... even though, yes, I eventually tweaked everything.3D - This TV is great for 3D. Prometheus, The Hobbit, Avatar, and even The Little Mermaid all look great. However, be careful, as many factors attribute to the quality of the 3D you're viewing. The player, the TV, the movie and your cables. Remember, to view in 3D with this TV, you will need: ACTIVE 3D Glasses (Best Buy, Amazon, etc) a 3D BluRay player, a 3D BluRay movie, and compatible 3D BluRay HDMI cables. They're called High Speed and can be found on Amazon for like 5 bucks. Also, the angle in which your viewing and the lighting conditions have played roles in my 3D viewing experience. Get your living room dark, and sit far enough away from the TV for great 3D viewing pleasure.SPECIAL NOTES: For proper 3D viewing, "Warming" up the display is recommended, according to the e-manual built into the TV's software. I've noticed this first hand. What happens is that launching a 3D movie right after intial boot up, the picture can and will likely display ghosting: the effect in 3D pictures where the 2 images are not properly aligned, creating a double image which outlines the primary picture. It's rather annoying and happens a lot on this TV. Unless, of course, you let the display warm up. What's a warm up? Just watch something. Anything. For about 5 minutes and everything should be fine.But what sucks about this TV?  Right, because lets face it, nothing is perfect.Sound - With low weight comes crap speakers in the TV world and this thing is terrible with sound. It has enough audio to get you going until you buy a sound-bar or a 5.1/7.1 system but overall the speakers are crap. But it's a con that is acceptable as I was also purchasing a sound-bar.Judder Reduction:  For some reason, on this set, high amounts of judder reduction (setting the slider to 10 instead of say, 4) introduces pixelation around fast moving objects. It's disgusting and terrible to see and once you notice it (because not everyone will) you will never be able to not notice it again. Its unfortunate because for me, it severely dampens one primary feature of this products, thus my 4 star review. Why even have the slider go so far up if it distorts the picture so much? Not good.Audio Sync - While a minor and almost completely eradicated problem, it was a problem none the less. For some unknown reasons, this set has the tenancy to lose sync with the video when outputting the audio. What you get is the actors finishing conversations but the dialogue is still going on. It's a little unnerving but since hooking my sound-bar up to my BluRay player, it's all but gone away. I haven't noticed it in months. When I did notice it, changing the sound settings and rebooting the TV seemed to help.Anyway, that's my 2 cents, as they say. Any questions feel free to ask. This TV is so wonderful that my brother bought the same exact model and he loves his as well. It's a wonderful TV but above $700, I'd say stay away.

Reviews.Title: All you need to Know
Reviews.Author: Suhr
Reviews.Content: I give this TV 5 stars due to Lack of Features.The "smart tv" requires that a multi core computer be integrated into the tv thus ramping up not only power consumed, but also creates excessive heat that shortens the lifespan of all semiconductors within the tv.This is not a smart TV.The picture and performance of this TV IS entertaining and a good purchase value.All you need are a few adjustments. (SEE ADJUSTMENTS BELOW.... copy and paste these adjustments to a text file and use them to help "dial in" your preferences, they are a good starting point and you can always reset the TV to Default with one click and begin again, record your adjustments and print them out for handy reference)Be absolutely certain to provide this or any other Samsung TV with excellent cooling space or a law of physics named negative temperature coefficient will cause instability problems.Off axis performance of this model is average at best with some clouding observable but not enough to truly complain.Picture and 3D imaging is very good and quite entertaining.On screen menu and remote control layout is excellent and easily understood.Overall.... an excellent choice for those who wish a large screen and 3D and is an excellent purchase value.My only technical complaint is that the WiFi transceivers cannot be powered off and pretty much every built in picture option (default) is Extremely Bright, bright enough to causes momentary eye pain. (easily adjusted)By the way.... I have never used the built in speakers of any modern TV. (purchase yourself an 1/8" mini stereo jack to RCA adapter cable (also called 3.5mm) for connection to a home stereo systems that do not use digital connection, this cable is Not Supplied)The picture on this TV is very sensitive to pink, magenta, and red, you will need to make some adjustments. (the natural light color of an LED is red so this is no surprise)The screen is a gloss finish and will require some room light placement that minimizes reflections. (not a matte finish)Last complaint is the lack of a built in strain relief for attached cables. A cable strain relief is supplied in the form of a stick-on gadget, but it is virtually useless and waiting to fail. (I designed my own strain relief)Here are some settings for a PROPERLY LIT VIEWING ROOM.A properly lit viewing room is basically identical to a movie theater, or in simple words, no lights.Since few follow this common sense practice.... these settings apply to a Dimly Lit room.Your television provider DOES alter the "actual" picture as an effort to minimize bandwidth requirements. (typically results in a much brighter picture) Don't make adjustments based upon broadcast signals, use a DVD or Blu Ray player.Once properly adjusted, you WILL notice substantial differences in the video picture between broadcast channels and programs including dramatic differences between TV commercials.That is Normal and indication of proper adjustments.Default adjustments supplied with the TV make virtually all video pictures identical.(over contrasted, over saturated, intense brights, intense darks)These adjustments produce a very neutral and realistic picture with high dynamic range.BEFORE YOU BEGIN!Welcome to the modern TV world.You MUST attach your new TV to the Internet and install the latest updates. (don't have internet?.... then you are "almost" out of luck)You "can" download the latest firmware update to a thumbdrive at Samsung.com. (best do this before the programmed obsolescence used by tech companies causes the updates to vanish)Either way.... an internet connection is required..... what is wrong with this picture?First things first. (Very Important) Can cause several odd picture behaviors.Under System....Energy Saver OffEco Sensor OffPICTURE----Picture Mode Standard**Backlight 0 (value varies from 0-4 depending on how bright the room is)Contrast 100Brightness 40Sharpness 50Color 49Tint G53/R47 (can vary slightly from TV to TV, look for too much pink in flesh tones)Advanced----Dynamic Contrast OffBlack Tone OffFlesh Tone 0RGB Only Mode OffColor Space NativeWhite BalanceR Offset 24G Offset 25B Offset 25R Gain 25G Gain 25B Gain 25Gamma 0Motion Lighting OffPicture Options----Color Tone StandardDigital Noise Filter AutoMPEG Noise Filter AutoHDMI Black Level NormalFilm Mode Auto2LED Motion Plus Off**Notes about Backlight.The Backlight adjustment produces a brighter picture overall and makes ALL things brighter. Watch the blacks while making this adjustment to see how it produces a clouding, or smokey effect that greatly reduces dynamic range between white and black.Backlight should only be used in very bright rooms and very sparingly.IF YOU PREFER MORE CONTRAST after making these adjustments, (less detail in blacks and whites) that produces a more dramatic picture.... then set HDMI Black Level to Low. (useful for broadcast programs, typically not needed for DVD / Blu Ray)ENJOY!POSTSCRIPT (details discovered over time)Know that there are two HDMI inputs to this TV.Each input has its own picture adjustment settings that are separate.I also discovered something somewhat odd....When playing a 3D movie, a separate picture setting also exists that affects the 3D picture only. So, in actuality there are three HDMI picture settings.The 3D settings are LIMITED and many adjustments are not available.Be prepared to make separate adjustments for 3D movie viewing. (the default 3D settings are very bright but do perform quite well due to the darkening effect created by the 3D glasses, I adjusted Backlight only, 2-4)IMPORTANT.... this is a Direct Quote from the Original Owners manual, the original owners manual has been replaced by a generic manual. (the generic manual also states this in fewer words)********************************************************************************************************************************************"Wide screen format LED Displays (16:9, the aspect ratio of the screen width to height) are primarily designed to view wide screen format full-motion video.The images displayed on them should primarily be in the wide screen 16:9 ratio format, or expanded to fill the screen if your model offers this feature and the images are constantly moving.Displaying stationary graphics and images on screen, such as the dark sidebars on non- expanded standard format television video and programming, should be limited to no more than 5% of the total television viewing per week.Additionally, viewing other stationary images and text such as stock market reports, video game displays, station logos, web sites or computer graphics and patterns, should be limited as described above for all televisions. Displaying stationary images that exceed the above guidelines can cause uneven aging of LED Displays that leave subtle, but permanent burned-in ghost images in the LED picture. To avoid this, vary the programming and images, and primarily display full screen moving images, not stationary patterns or dark bars. On LED models that offer picture sizing features, use these controls to view different formats as a full screen picture. Be careful in the selection and duration of television formats you use for viewing. Uneven LED aging as a result of format selection and use, as well as burned-in images, are not covered by your Samsung limited warranty."********************************************************************************************************************************************Do the math.... for an average viewing time of 42 hours per week you can watch one 2 hour movie with an aspect ratio of 2:35 or 2:40 or 4:3 per week.Or in simplistic terms, a full screen (4:3) OR letterboxed movie that has black bars.Full screen or 4:3 movie can be made to consume the entire screen at loss of clarity by using the Wide Fit option under Screen Adjustment.2:35 aspect ratio movie cannot be viewed without letterboxing unless your DVD / Blu Ray Player has a Zoom function and this will reduce clarity and cause some pixelation.Best bet is to purchase movies that are 1:85 aspect ratio.This causes a problem since so many modern movies are 2:35 aspect ratio.(the studio refuses to crop 2:35 aspect ratio movies to 1:85 because the studio regards HD TV engineering design and specification requirements as Not Important even though.... EVERY MOVIE is cropped from its original source form. For DECADES, the top, bottom, and sides of all movies have been cropped. How do you suppose they get rid of shotgun mikes on booms? (explains why so many shots clip off the tops of heads) This cropping process remains utilized today on all widescreen format movies.... you Never see the "entire" picture. Widescreen formats are based upon the geometry of theaters.... theaters that ALSO crop the image to prevent displaying the projected image on the walls, floor, and ceiling.... shutters)So, Owner Beware!.... improper aspect movies can harm your new TV and is not covered under warranty.Here is a hands on explanation regarding aspect ratios and with regard to efforts you should consider to prevent "Burn In" not covered under warranty.If you are viewing a 2:35 aspect ratio that is a broadcast program you have the options of Zoom 1 and Zoom 2 in most cases.Zoom 1 will fill the screen with a 2:35 aspect ratio broadcast. (Zoom 2 is simply a zoomed version of Zoom 1 and useful for old CinemaScope or PanaVision movies and will stretch the image, makes all look taller and skinnier)The reason you can do this to a broadcast show is because it is not truly HD content despite that it is advertised AS.... HD. (some exceptions will apply)If you are on the HDMI 2 (HDMI/DVI) input attached to a DVD or Blu Ray player, the Zoom 1 and Zoom 2 options are not available if you are viewing a 2:4 (or 2:35) aspect ratio that is from a Blu ray disc.For a hands on experiment you will need a 2:4 aspect ratio movie that contains a DVD and Blu Ray version of the movie.What you will witness (with this TV and "most" blu ray players) is that you cannot make the movie consume the entire screen while playing the blu ray version.That is because of the pixel density causing a data stream that cannot be altered due to data rate.Play the DVD version of the exact same movie and you will be able to cause the movie to consume the entire screen. (it WILL be cropped)Are you "missing" part of the movie if it consumes the entire screen?.... Yes.Now ask yourself.... why did you buy a 55 inch HD TV?Was it to display one third of the screen in ultra high clarity and high definition black bars?Now ask the core question.Why are movie makers doing this?"They" KNOW that you have a 16:9 TV and did not buy a widescreen HD TV to watch high definition black bars. "They" KNOW that your aspect ratio is 1:77 or 1:85.WHY????The answer is.... someday.... the next "new" HD TV will be produced in a 2:4  or 2:35 aspect ratio as well as "new" blu ray players.This will entice, promote, elicit, and solicit YOU to replace your perfectly functioning 16:9 TV and possibly replace your blu ray player with the latest and greatest model.It's called Capitalism. (how else can you be convinced to buy something new?.... perhaps????.... it's because your 16:9 TV has "Burn In" from watching incorrect aspect ratio movies in a letterbox?)In the meantime.... is it wise to create "Burn In" on your new TV?What matters most?HUMOR: I must admit, the BLACK BARS on these wacko ratio letterboxed blu ray movies ARE extremely high definition..... just as high definition as the rest of the movie.Getting rid of my old 4:3 TV was supposed to solve the problems of watching widescreen movies in a letterbox.... Oh Well.Here is how the Zoom and Wide Fit will function.If you choose either Zoom or Wide Fit, this TV will apply those settings to any broadcast channel that is not 1920x1080 and will Not apply those settings to a true HD picture Automatically.For example, say you have an old 4:3 movie (Full Frame) and you select Wide Fit to prevent burn in.This setting will apply to any movie you watch that is not 1920x1080 and this setting will not go away unless you manually change it. (it is Semi Automatic and is a setting unique and separate to each HDMI input)If you choose Zoom, this setting will apply to all movies and channels EXCEPT true HD content regardless of aspect ratio.You cannot Zoom a 2:35 or 2:4 Blu Ray movie or true HD content on this TV.In the case of broadcast programming.... the durn commercials are virtually all a 1:85 ratio and this annoying alteration helps prevent burn in if watching a letterboxed broadcast program. (no need to worry about burn in)Obviously this is not true for premium broadcast movie channels.Well boys and girls, it is time to observe REALITY.At least the aspect ratio portion of this review sounds like an opinion.How does a person make a statement that is not an opinion?The answer is, share a repeatable experiment.THE ASPECT RATIO ISSUE:The arguments I have received regarding movies that are letterboxed or incorrect aspect ratio IS....If the movie fills the entire screen, you are missing part of the movie. (it is cropped)No matter what I have stated, this is ALWAYS the argument for having one third of your big widescreen HD TV show nothing but black.EVIDENTLY these persons failed to realize that I was specifically referencing NEW MOVIES.Here is the experiment and conditions.The vast and overwhelming number (if not ALL) HD Widescreen TV's that exist today on planet earth are 16:9 aspect ratio or 1.77 or 1.85.Buy the blu ray movie "Epic" and watch it on your magnificent 16:9 HD TV and what do you see?You will see a letterboxed movie and one third of your TV screen is nothing but black bars.Here comes that argument.... "if it wasn't letterboxed, you would be missing part of the movie".Really????The movie "Epic" 3D is Entirely Computer Generated. Did that fly by too fast?"Epic" 3D was not "shot, or "filmed" in an oddball or incorrect aspect ratio.The entire movie could have been produced in the proper 16:9 aspect ratio At The Drawing Board and not one single scene or part of a scene would be missing in any way whatsoever!If that were not insult enough to intelligence.... the movie Menu is in 3D and IS the proper aspect ratio, (1:85), until you hit Play.WHY???? is that!Who? wants to watch a movie that only uses 2/3 of your HD TV screen?.... "who" is... everyone who says they are missing part of the movie if it is not letterboxed.That IS an OPINION that does not validate itself because any and all new movies should and can be produced to Fit your entire 16:9 TV screen without any portion of the movie missing and without any technical restrictions.I did not share an opinion.There MUST be a reason that new movies do not fit your new TV's screen.I can derive only one answer.1. You need to buy a new 2.4:1 TV in the future, (a TV that is 2.4 times wider than it is tall), because your expensive brand new 16:9 HD TV was obsolete junk the instant you bought it.(spare yourself the time and effort, there is no rational or technical excuse for oddball aspect ratios on new movies, especially CG movies)After using this TV for some time, I experienced a problem that seems to be fairly common.The sound becomes out of sync, or delayed, or not aligned.This has been reported on several models, not just this model.As a technical professional I sought an explanation because the problem is intermittent, the worst kind of problem because it is not actually broken.Here is what I discovered.I had a friend who uses a completely different brand and type of TV (plasma) and reported that this happened to him as well, intermittently of course.The source of the problem is not the TV, it is the broadcast. My friend and I share the same broadcast service provider.Not all broadcast clients have this problem, why????The reason is the Modem. The modem is your cable box or similar. Not all Modems provided by the broadcast service are the same model and can have intermittent problems.(also.... interference levels vary from house to house)So, before you return your TV as broken, check to see if the problem persists for more than a week.... AND.... change the On/Off sequence.Try turning the cable box on Before the TV is turned on.(verify intermittent audio delay condition by playing a DVD or Blu Ray disc)You see.... HDMI is Not a video or audio signal.... it is 1's and 0's ONLY and a hand shake synchronization must be established in proper order.It only takes a couple of missing bits to create an out of sync condition between audio and video bitstreams.All it takes to miss a few bits is a source of electromagnetic interference, including, ham radios, radars, solar activity and even.... WiFi transceivers.The intermittent problem can be reduced by using a quality HDMI cable but cannot be eliminated if the source is a broadcast service provider problem.In RARE cases this problem will persist.Contact your broadcast service provider and request a new Modem.Bottom line, if this audio out of sync problem does not occur with a directly connected DVD or Blu Ray player then it is a broadcast signal problem.My recurring audio-out-of-sync events occurred when my cable company was updating and remapping broadcast channels and has stopped since.(CAN be a flaky HDMI cable or dirty jack connection that persists regardless if the cable is replaced... make certain all cables and jacks are squeaky clean)I refuse to elucidate on any further possible conditions because this review would become a book.Besides.... most everything else you "need to know" is in your owner's manual.

Reviews.Title: Great for the price
Reviews.Author: Cerveau
Reviews.Content: I've had a 42" LCD Vizio and my room mate has a 50" Plasma. This by far looks the best, and it sounds a lot better than I expected. I played a quick round of BF4 and it looked and sounded fantastic. I wouldn't expect to make the house rumble with fat beats but its loud and sounds crisp for games or viewing. For the money its worth it.

Reviews.Title: good tv to own.
Reviews.Author: michel colby
Reviews.Content: The samsung 46-inch TV, has an excellent picture and the the sound is very clear . the only thing we don,t like is that it is light sensitive.We have to have the ceiling light on at all times.

Reviews.Title: Great TV!!!
Reviews.Author: Heather Kingseed
Reviews.Content: I ordered this TV during the week of Black Friday and was a little concerned about the quality since the pictures didn't really seem to show too much. The price was too good to pass up, however, so I took a chance. The delivery process was great! They scheduled the delivery and showed up well within the time frame. The guy unpacked the TV so that we could ensure it was ok.The TV has an amazing picture! According to the info on Amazon's website, it only has 120 Hz, but the TV I received is 240Hz! It is also a 3D TV; I noticed another reviewer mentioned that (since the comparison chart says that it isn't). It seems to be a really amazing TV. I am extremely pleased with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great buy, plug in an ethernet cable!
Reviews.Author: ryan closter
Reviews.Content: awesome tv, would highly recommend it. One feature i am really stoked about is the ability to use allshare through an ethernet cable. I am able to stream any movie from my computer or phone in every format I have tried in high quality. speakers are good and once i turned off the ecoboost nonsense it was good to go.  The only negative I could find was that the stand is a little rickity . I feel nervous trying to get behind this television and would reccomend a wall mount. other than that awesome buy and if it has gone up in price again it is still only $800 on Samsungs website as of 11-29-13.

Reviews.Title: Excellent picture, very sensitive on-the-air tuner.
Reviews.Author: JA
Reviews.Content: We purchased this to replace a 13 year old JVC cathode ray tube TV with an external digital tuner for digital on-the-air signals and a satellite box attached.  We first tried a Panasonic TC-L39EM60 39-Inch 1080p 120Hz LED HDTV but it had a less sensitive tuner and some other major problems I describe more in my review of that item.  We next tried this Samsung TV.  Not only did it set up quite easily, but it found nearly twice as many on-the-air stations as the old JVC TV with its external digital tuner did.  Moreover, it has a sharp, brilliant picture that adjusts itself for lighting conditions in the room.  Extremely delighted with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Very Nice...
Reviews.Author: DaFaDa
Reviews.Content: I purchased the 46" version.The hardest part of the setup was the 4 screws in the base. Not too heavy; easy to put in its cabinet and position.Digital setup was also easy, getting through the basic settings. Additional settings are varied and many, and will take some time to get them all right, but I would rather have more options than less.Out of the box the picture is amazing; very bright, movement is smooth color is rich. It's interesting as I experience the so called "Soap Opera" effect with the picture for the first time, figure out how to get rid of it, and now try to decide which way I like it best.Device is NOT a smart TV, which is what I wanted, but it does have a LAN port which I supposed is to be used for Firmware updates.Have not tried the 3D yet but I'm sure it will be Kewl once I get there.What they say about size is true:I waffled between the 40" and the 46" (Going up from a 32"), and decided on a 46". Within reason, it is better bigger than smaller.

Reviews.Title: GREAT once you change Factory Settings!
Reviews.Author: N.Kovarik
Reviews.Content: As part of the shipping provided from Amazon, I received FREE "White Glove" delivery.  This included the delivery company (CEVA) scheduling an appointment with a flexible timeframe, carrying the TV into any room in the house, unboxing it, installing the TV Stand/Base for me, plugging it in, and testing the TV through any desired input (HDMI, Cable TV, whatever you wanted) to ensure no physical or quality defects before leaving it in my hands.  MOST IMPORTANT thing to do when first setting up this particular model, go through the one-time setup, and immediately go into the Menu --> Picture & System Settings --> Advanced Settings, and do the following:**Eco Sensor: OFF (automatic brightness based on room lighting through a sensor on the TV)**Auto Motion Plus: OFF**Then choose a basic picture quality (Standard, Natural, Dynamic, etc based on your liking).  I'm not an advanced video-fanatic but I wanted the TV and colors to "pop" and look similar to how the floor-models are setup without being over-the-top and too unnatural looking (mix between 75% Vibrant, 25% Natural so-to-speak); so I went with Dynamic and THEN (important):**Turn the Brightness and Backlight DOWN to a more suitable level. By default, the Brightness is so high that it washes out almost every color; leaving you with a disappointing picture that will make you want to return it at first (but don't, it looks GREAT after it's adjusted).  Finally, if you did not have a 1080p TV before this one, go into your individual devices (such as a Playstation 3) and re-setup your Video/Output settings to go up to 1080p.  I previously had a 720p TV and the PS3, Xbox, and Networked PC did NOT automatically adjust to 1080p output, and had to be setup manually, otherwise you have an expensive TV operating at a lesser quality perminantly.  If Samsung is your go-to TV because you want an amazingly vibrant HD TV, but are also aware there's cheaper (and lower quality) brands out there, this is the best you will find for the money, size, and features.

Reviews.Title: 2D to 3D content is AMAZING!!
Reviews.Author: Kat B.
Reviews.Content: I have had this TV for a week now (bday pres to myself :-)) and I really could not be happier I choose this specific make and model! It, hands down, has the best HD picture I've ever seen! It's like looking out of a window.  There is a small amount of motion blur on high action scenes due to the size, but once you tweak the settings a bit, it's very easy to reduce it to almost none.  Samsung has made it so easy to literally adjust everything on this TV to your specific liking. You can even change the depth of your 3D if you like it more or less 3 dimensional... and even switch the 3D settings to your specific dominate eye if you have poor vision in one eye! You can pretty much customize every part of this TV. I really cant say enough about it! Having the 3D instead of the Smart TV was a no brainer for us. We have a 3D Smart Sony Vizio TV and we almost never use the smart features.  Anytime I need to get online and want to view it through my TV (movies and such), I just plug my pc up to TV via HDMI and viola, the "smartest" smart TV you ask for! Not to mention that my blue ray player has all the apps built-in to it that I want anyway. The only issue I've ever had with 3D is the lack of 3D content offered by most cable providers, but now Samsung has resolved that issue as well with this specific set. Having the 2D to 3D conversion makes it almost too easy to enjoy anything in 3D ;-)... if I'm in a 3D kinda mood, I can transform anything on my TV directly into an awesome 3D experience with just the touch of a button! I highly recommend this TV to anyone who enjoys watching 3D! But remember, this set does not include the 3D glasses, and you can't substitute any other type of glasses..it has to be Samsung Active glasses. Hope y'all enjoy this TV as much as I am :-)

Reviews.Title: Samsung
Reviews.Author: Bruce Emerson
Reviews.Content: it's the greatest LED TV I ever had, the picture is amazing the sound is great.  I would recommend this TV to any of my friends

Reviews.Title: Great TV for gaming!!!
Reviews.Author: Erik Saldivar
Reviews.Content: I was looking to upgrade my TV mostly for gaming and Netflix. After looking at some TV's that met my budget, I decided to go with this one. Not regretting it one bit!!! The refresh rate is awesome when it comes to gaming, and the picture looks amazing. Other reviews were right on having to modify the settings a bit to meet your satisfaction. Also you have to make sure it is running on the latest software update via internet connection. Other than that I highly recommend this TV for anyone looking to game on or Netflix it up. Had this TV for a month now and I'm loving it!!!

Reviews.Title: I love this TV!
Reviews.Author: Nick Griff
Reviews.Content: What a great TV! For the money (I got this on a black Friday special), this display is awesome. I was looking for a non-smart TV since I have an XBOX360 and a smart phone and came across this beauty. As I've seen other people mention, the picture quality is pretty poor right out of the box, but after some tweaking, its perfect. I did a Google search to see what settings other people were using and there was a lot of helpful information out there to get the picture just right. As far as the sound quality goes, it leaves something to be desired, but then again, most TV speakers I've come across just aren't that great. My absolute favorite feature of this TV (and something almost everybody out there seems to overlook) is the ability to up-convert 2D content to 3D. This display doesn't come with 3D glasses (which cuts down on the cost of the unit) but I found great pair for less than $20 each on Amazon. The 3D quality is far better than I would have expected. For the price I paid, I'm extremely happy with what I got. The only downside to this display I've found so far is that you have to buy a separate component to use WiFi, otherwise you need to use an Ethernet cable to connect to the internet. I highly recommend this display for anyone looking to save money over a "smart" TV and gain 3D capability instead.

Reviews.Title: Port failure?
Reviews.Author: Amazoner
Reviews.Content: Great TV with good colors, but some of the ports on the TV doesn't seem to work all the time. Have to re-click sources several times to connect to PC.

Reviews.Title: Great TV, no complaints!
Reviews.Author: Dante Moten
Reviews.Content: I've had this TV for about 2 to 3 weeks, and I must say it is amazing! The picture is immaculate, and may require a little tweaking. The 3-D is flawless! And it is able to convert three types of 3d: over and under, side-by-side, and convert 2-D to 3-D (the least flattering). Overall, I'm very satisfied with this TV, and would recommend it to anyone in search of a high quality Samsung TV well worth the money.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: John Doe "John"
Reviews.Content: Pros:Very Light weightHD Tuner, no need for our old external tuner & wiresNot a smart tvRemote lights up, has previous channel button and a few other nice features, like the manual integrated into the tv.Software on tv is already up to date.Cons2 HDMI ports, but good enough for my purposesPower cord seems a bit short, i'm guessing 4 ft, though the plug doesn't stick out from the tv and has a right angle immediately on the power intake.The port design doesn't make much sense because they don't go out from the side, they just go straight back so you have to have some room behind the TV.It has the awkward smooth motion, but I thought it was better than what I've seen with the Sony Bravia from 2 years back (haven't noticed any weird dimming like the bravia's either)Hung it to the wall with B000WYVBR0**UPDATE**I tried to hook up to the USB port to play an mp4 and it sort of worked.  The TV's graphics card couldn't keep up with the frame rate so the video was very choppy.  Though it did actually "play" the mp4 unlike my blu-ray player that says it plays mp4's and doesn't at all.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful picture, but sound is so-so
Reviews.Author: S. Petrovich "Just dancin'"
Reviews.Content: We have had this TV for several months now.  We cannot get over how gorgeous the picture looks!  So bright and clear!  I am very happy with this purchase.  But the sound is poor.  When you play a DVD like Star Trek Into Darkness, we have a hard time getting good sound out of the TV--the dialog is hard to hear but the action sounds are too loud.  We've tried every kind of sound setting the TV has, but we cannot find a good medium between dialog and action.  I think we'll just have to buy extra speakers.  But that doesn't stop us from loving this TV.

Reviews.Title: Love this TV
Reviews.Author: S. Conley "pitbull"
Reviews.Content: Awesome TV.  Came preloaded with the pic settings a bit off creating that Soap-operary look to it but a few adjustments and it looks normal.  The 3D images on blu ray and on downloaded content are great.  The 2D-3D conversion for normal TV viewing is pretty much worthless so a little disappointed in that aspect.  Great sound for a rear speaker system and awesome picture.  Light as a penny when you think about those old tube-style televisions that weighed upwards of 100 lbs.

Reviews.Title: The Big Picture
Reviews.Author: Phillip G.
Reviews.Content: This was my first Big Screen purchase.  I wanted something that was at leat 50 to 55 inches that was not going to break the bank and I did not want a" No Named" brand that was suposed to be just as good.  Cant go wrong with Samsung.  Beautiful picture and sound quality.  It is a little thicker than some of the new flat screens but it is still wall mountable and the price was truely amazing for all that you get.  I also was not interested in the "smart TV" because I have Uverse and an apple TV and between both of those its enough.

Reviews.Title: Big Kahuna
Reviews.Author: shopenhauzer "shopenhauzer"
Reviews.Content: Switched from a Vizio M321i-A2 32-Inch to Samsung model UN40FH6030. Required reverse re-thinking + re-viewing after re-reading Cnet's glowing hosannas of all LEDs Vizio for whatever their reasoning's worth anymore. Well, Sony's pretty much out of the mid-range tier of hdtv competition now so that leaves us with the big guns Vizio, Panasonic, LG, Toshiba, Samsung & assorted lesser wannabes like Haier, Coby, etc. Not a lot, especially if there's such a thing as a budget. What can you get for around $4-500 price range in this brave new world of pre-2014? You can settle for a smart Vizio 32-Inch with, yea a "Razor" sharp picture splashed all over their boxes, not to mention deep black levels, not bad sound + rugged, stylish stand, but you will also have to swallow the terrible color saturation only barely hinted at by guilty culprits such as Cnet and various techno-related reviewers online. You're stuck with an extreme of over-saturated color where everyone looks like they overdosed on Coppertone or you can turn it down to washed out, semi-vampiric levels. Maybe it was just the unlucky lemon I was unfortunately duped into buying, but I suspect the yellowish, jaundiced flesh tones I could not color-correct under any built-in, pre-set combo is symptomatic of something intrinsic to their much-ballyhooed "M" series. The tv picture always reminded me of black & white photographs colorized - that bad. So draw your own conclusions on these so-called experts and specialists.The remedy as it turned out dwindled down to what more and more looks like the only game in town for mid-range hdtvs now:Samsung. What my eyes sorely craved was color saturation. Deep, penetrating, robust, healthy, natural-looking, real human beings. Not pasty-toned zombies spilling over from the "Walking Dead" infiltrating the rest of my tv shows and movies, not to mention the commercials even. So, lo and behold, I discover what sounds like reasonable deal for this Samsung 40-inch equipped with all my fave specs: 1080p, 120 refresh, good dynamics + 3d-enabled, to boot. Only thing missing is "smart" wifi which sure ain't the deal-breaker it was three-score years ago, especially if you already got Apple TV like I do or Roku box, etc. Maybe "smart" tv era IS over and done with before we even knew it, bye. Anyway, you get ethernet.To summarize, clocking in at a svelte 25 lbs with direct-LED backlight, this Samsung is a light-weight powerhouse that blows the ever-lovin' wilted petunias off said Vizio. Ok, it is a 40-Inch vs a Vizio 32-Inch, granted, but the picture quality alone will suffice with plenty sharp enough image, thank you. The price differential is not that much for what you get. Color saturation is sublime with generous fine-tuning controls and the built-in frame rate customization is a trip, to say the least. Cnet never stops whining about the "notorious" Samsung black levels (or lack thereof) - any model - and honestly, my eyes can't discern any noticeable difference between this and the Vizio. If the blacks are still not deep enough for you, then that's what the black level control is there for. And maybe try activating the color dynamics while you're at it! I won't even go into the common, off-angle viewing complaint which seems to be the nature of the beast for these devices. Live with it. 16:9 setting works best for overall picture size. Only thing really bugged me was the ridiculously tiny, cheesy .25-inch screws & holes for the stand assembly. Samsung, can you give us a break? Luckily I had some tougher, longer screws of my own which fit into the sockets - word to the wise! The only difficult task involved setting up this baby. The rest as they say was gravy. Hope it helps.

Reviews.Title: Very pleased so far.
Reviews.Author: Richard
Reviews.Content: Packed carefully/thoughtfully at the factory. So easy to set up. So light in weight. Very user friendly.  Almost plug and play after installing the TV on it's stand. Made some minor adjustments from factory setting. Picture is beautiful and true in color. Sharp. Independently ordered 3D glasses since they are not included with the TV. Setup for 3D is seamless and really a no brainer. TV tells me when the glasses are synced with it. Rented Frozen 3D on VUDU to test the 3D, and it is beautiful. The TV replaces a Panny 42" E3 which was already beautiful at 60Hz in 2D. That one is in the bedroom now. The Sammy beats the Panny for me with a prettier picture, 120/240Hz, and a larger screen size + the 3D option. Very pleased so far. Connected to a Yamaha YHT 397 home theater at 5.1 so everything goes into 1 HDMI port. The remote is smallish, but adequate (I use my cable remote anyway once I adjusted the TV settings). Nice if the glasses came with the set, but whaddya gonna do. 4.8 stars.

Reviews.Title: Looks great
Reviews.Author: Ed Figueroa
Reviews.Content: Great TV for the price...but unfortunately it only has 2 HDMI ports. All of my older TV's have had more. Be sure to pick up a good HDMI splitter if you decide to get one of these.

Reviews.Title: Best value for a 55" 120hz 3d LED tv on the market!
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: I bought this on sale for $799 in free Sears gift cards from Discover $45 for $50 so it was basically free. The picture on this tv looks amazing after tweaking the settings which took some time to get right. I had a sound sync problem initially but solved it by turning components on first and letting them boot up fully before turning on the tv(frustrating problem i hope this helps someone). The auto motion plus is a little tricky i set it to custom blur reduction: 10 Judder reduction: 2-3 or off! lol. Turn off the dynamic contrast as it makes the picture too bright and there are back-light, contrast, brightness and gamma settings already. The tv plays h.264, mkv, divx plus hd files and many more right from the built in usb port in the side and in 3d no less(no 3d player required) The 2d-3d up-conversion is great but the 3d movies on this are amazing and crystal clear! Also this tv lets you convert your 3d movies to 2d for casual viewing. This has 2 types of audio out digital op cable or headphone jack which can easily be adapted to 2 rca for older systems. The only real con is that the component(RGB) port is shared with the composite(standard yellow ) jack which sucks if you have some older non HDMI equipment but a good modulator can solve this. The cheap $19.99 samsung 3d glasses work great and you can buy rechargeable coin batteries for them online. All in all this tv has one of the best pictures i have ever seen and represents a very good value for the money.

Reviews.Title: A really great TV!!
Reviews.Author: kevin45
Reviews.Content: This TV is really great, it has so many good specs and for its price I think its literally a steal! I'm a gamer so I needed a TV that had good refresh rates and decent picture quality, this TV not only offered me both but it threw in a set of decent speakers too. I've yet to connect my surround system to it, cause the sound quality is that good! Here are a few pros and con's I've noticed with this TV.Pros:-lightweight (literally the weight of a 17" laptop)-great picture quality (customers complained of ghosting and stuff, I didn't notice that at all, besides I customized my picture quality so it looks better than the preset modes, which are also not bad)-great sound (this I didn't customize much, out of the box it sounded great)-decent added features.- pricingCons:- USB slot (this TV has a USB slot you can use to view photos or videos, its great and all but it has limited processing power not sure of its limits but I have two disk drives both are a terabyte each, one is completely full and the other just has about 20 GB worth of stuff. The TV can read and play the lesser content HDD but if I tried the other it reads it but  crashes the TV before my video or picture files can be opened, however its a lot of files so I understand. I don't see this being a problem for most people, but just thought I should highlight it)Internet: its an internet TV which is good but it needs an Ethernet cable which for me is bad. (I prefer WiFi. Again for most this isn't an issue)3D: nice to say you have a 3D TV but seeing as I have to buy glasses for it. I'm not too excited about that ( again not a problem for most the feature works fine with 3D related media.)Finally it's a great TV for its price, movies and games look brilliant, its added features actually do work if you require them. So yeah if you have the money I would recommend this anytime.
